title: Patriots injury report: Christian Gonzalez, Keion White ruled out vs. Dolphins
author: Kaley Brown
bullets: Patriots' CB Christian Gonzalez and DE Keion White ruled out for Sunday’s game against the Miami Dolphins.
Gonzalez has been sidelined since July 28 with a hamstring injury; White out due to illness.
LB Marte Mapu and OT Morgan Moses are questionable; both participated in practice with limited capacity.

title: With DC Terrell Williams out, who will be calling defensive plays for Patriots vs. Dolphins?
author: Conor Roche
bullets: Patriots linebackers coach Zak Kuhr will call defensive plays against the Dolphins due to Terrell Williams's health absence.
Kuhr, previously an assistant with Ohio State and the Titans, fills in for Williams who left for an undisclosed health issue.
Mike Vrabel supports Kuhr calling plays; players are familiar with his style from practice sessions this spring.

title: Boston activist Monica Cannon-Grant to plead guilty in federal fraud case
author: Abby Patkin
bullets: Monica Cannon-Grant will plead guilty to federal fraud charges before her U.S. District Court trial in Boston.
Cannon-Grant and her late husband allegedly misused funds from their nonprofit, Violence in Boston, for personal expenses.
She faces a 27-count indictment, including wire fraud, mail fraud, and making false statements on mortgage applications.

title: Here’s what we know about Tyler Robinson, Charlie Kirk’s alleged assassin
author: The Associated Press
bullets: Tyler Robinson, 22, of Washington, Utah, charged with the murder of Charlie Kirk, was arrested without bail.
Robinson, a student at Dixie Technical College, had recently become more politically active, according to his family.
Messages on Discord and ammunition at the scene linked Robinson to the shooting, authorities reported.

title: 7 things to know about a pivotal Red Sox-Yankees series
author: Conor Roche
bullets: The Red Sox and Yankees are closely competing for the top American League wild-card spot and division title.
Boston leads the season series against New York 8-2, winning five of six games over the Yankees in June.
Max Fried, Luis Gil, and Will Warren will start for the Yankees, while Lucas Giolito, Brayan Bello, and Garrett Crochet pitch for Boston.

title: Winthrop loses $1.2M in climate grants over MBTA Communities Act noncompliance
author: Annie Jonas
bullets: Winthrop lost $1.2 million in state climate grants due to noncompliance with the MBTA Communities Act.
Executive Office of Energy and Environmental Affairs denied $819,829 and $405,020 grants for Morton Street and Fishermen's Bend.
Town Council's rejection of zoning proposal prevents compliance, impacting flood mitigation plans in vulnerable neighborhoods.

title: Healey orders flags at state buildings flown at half-staff to honor Charlie Kirk
author: Abby Patkin
bullets: Flags in Massachusetts will be flown at half-staff until sunset Sept. 14 to honor Charlie Kirk.
Gov. Maura Healey's order follows a presidential proclamation after Kirk's assassination at Utah Valley University.
A suspect, Tyler Robinson, has been arrested; motive remains unclear but was reportedly becoming more political.

title: A family-friendly guide to apple picking in New England
author: Kristi Palma
bullets: Honey Pot Hill Orchards in Stow offers mazes, barn animals, and cider doughnuts, rated the best in New England by Boston.com readers.
Cider Hill Farm in Amesbury features apple picking, a giant sandbox, a trike yard, and a farm store with unique culinary options.
Shelburne Orchards in Vermont hosts children's events including music and story time, alongside tractor rides and a taco truck.

title: Judge tosses ordinance limiting tear gas, rubber bullet use by Boston police
author: Abby Patkin
bullets: Judge Jackie Cowin ruled Boston City Council overstepped authority with an ordinance on police weapon use.
The 2021 ordinance required rigorous conditions for police to use tear gas, rubber bullets at public gatherings.
Mayor Michelle Wu's office has not commented on whether the city will appeal the judge's decision.

title: Did a Brooklyn couple kill a neighbor’s trees for a better view in Maine?
author: New York Times Service
bullets: Maine's Board of Pesticides Control accuses Stephen Antonson and Kathleen Hackett of poisoning trees for a harbor view.
Ruth Graham, a 95-year-old neighbor, found her trees withered and dying, prompting an investigation.
The Antonson-Hackett family denies involvement, but discussions are ongoing about a potential penalty fine.
